frames.primitives

Class Frame

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.primitives.Frame
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Node

    public class Frame
extends java.lang.Object
    A frame is a 2D or 3D coordinate system, represented by a position(), an orientation() and magnitude(). The order of these transformations is important: the frame is first translated, then rotated around the new translated origin and then scaled. This class API aims to conform that of the great libQGLViewer Frame, but it adds magnitude() to it.

    Geometry transformations

    A frame is useful to define the position, orientation and magnitude of an object, using its matrix() method, as shown below:

    // Builds a frame at position (0.5,0,0) and oriented such that its Y axis is along the (1,1,1) direction
    Frame frame = new Frame(new Vector(0.5,0,0), new Quaternion(new Vector(0,1,0), new Vector(1,1,1)));
    graph.pushModelView();
    graph.applyModelView(frame.matrix());
    // Draw your object here, in the local frame coordinate system.
    graph.popModelView();

    Many functions are provided to transform a point from one frame to another, see coordinatesOf(Vector), inverseCoordinatesOf(Vector), coordinatesOfIn(Vector, Frame), coordinatesOfFrom(Vector, Frame)...

    You may also want to transform a vector (such as a normal), which corresponds to applying only the rotational part of the frame transformation: see transformOf(Vector) and inverseTransformOf(Vector).

    The translation(), rotation() and uniform positive scaling() that are encapsulated in a frame can also be used to represent an angle preserving transformation of space. Such a transformation can also be interpreted as a change of coordinate system, and the coordinate system conversion functions actually allow you to use a frame as an angle preserving transformation. Use inverseCoordinatesOf(Vector) (resp. coordinatesOf(Vector)) to apply the transformation (resp. its inverse). Note the inversion.

    Hierarchy of frames

    The frame position, orientation and magnitude are actually defined with respect to a reference() frame. The default reference() is the world coordinate system (represented by a null reference()). If you setReference(Frame) to a different frame, you must then differentiate:
    • The local translation(), rotation() and scaling(), defined with respect to the reference().
    • the global position(), orientation() and magnitude(), always defined with respect to the world coordinate system.

    A frame is actually defined by its translation() with respect to its reference(), then by rotation() of the coordinate system around the new translated origin and then by a uniform positive scaling() along its rotated axes.

    This terminology for local (translation(), rotation() and scaling()) and global (position(), orientation() and magnitude()) definitions is used in all the methods' names and should be enough to prevent ambiguities. These notions are obviously identical when the reference() is null, i.e., when the frame is defined in the world coordinate system (the one you are left with after calling a graph preDraw() method).

    Frames can hence easily be organized in a tree hierarchy, which root is the world coordinate system. A loop in the hierarchy would result in an inconsistent (multiple) frame definition. Therefore settingAsReferenceWillCreateALoop(Frame) checks this and prevents reference() from creating such a loop.

    This frame hierarchy is used in methods like coordinatesOfIn(Vector, Frame), coordinatesOfFrom(Vector, Frame) ... which allow coordinates (or vector) conversions from a frame to any other one (including the world coordinate system).

    Constraints

    One interesting feature of a frame is that its displacements can be constrained. When a Constraint is attached to a frame, it filters the input of translate(Vector) and rotate(Quaternion), and only the resulting filtered motion is applied to the frame. The default constraint() is null resulting in no filtering. Use setConstraint(Constraint) to attach a constraint to a frame.

    Classical constraints are provided for convenience (see LocalConstraint, WorldConstraint and EyeConstraint) and new constraints can very easily be implemented.

    Syncing

    Two frames can be synced together (sync(Frame, Frame)), meaning that they will share their global parameters (position, orientation and magnitude) taken the one that has been most recently updated. Syncing can be useful to share frames among different off-screen canvases.

      • randomize

        public void randomize(Vector center,
                      float radius)
        Randomized this frame. The frame is randomly re-positioned inside the ball defined by center and radius (see Vector.random()). The orientation() is randomized by Quaternion.randomize(). The new magnitude is a random in oldMagnitude * [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        random(Vector, float)

      • random

        public static Frame random(Vector center,
                           float radius)
        Returns a random frame. The frame is randomly positioned inside the ball defined by center and radius (see Vector.random()). The orientation() is set by Quaternion.random(). The magnitude is a random in [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        randomize(Vector, float)

      • sync

        public static void sync(Frame frame1,
                        Frame frame2)
        If frame1 has been more recently updated than frame2, calls frame2.setWorldMatrix(frame1), otherwise calls frame1.setWorldMatrix(frame2). Does nothing if both objects were updated at the same time.

        This method syncs only the global geometry attributes (position(), orientation() and magnitude()) among the two frames. The reference() and constraint() (if any) of each frame are kept separately.

        See Also:
        setWorldMatrix(Frame)

      • reference

        public Frame reference()
        Returns the reference frame, in which this frame is defined.

        The frame translation(), rotation() and scaling() are defined with respect to the reference() coordinate system. A null reference frame (default value) means that the frame is defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use position(), orientation() and magnitude() to recursively convert values along the reference frame chain and to get values expressed in the world coordinate system. The values match when the reference frame is null.

        Use setReference(Frame) to set this value and create a frame hierarchy. Convenient functions allow you to convert coordinates from one frame to another: see coordinatesOf(Vector), localCoordinatesOf(Vector) , coordinatesOfIn(Vector, Frame) and their inverse functions.

        Vectors can also be converted using transformOf(Vector), transformOfIn(Vector, Frame), localTransformOf(Vector) and their inverse functions.

      • setReference

        public void setReference(Frame reference)
        Sets the reference() of the frame.

        The frame translation(), rotation() and scaling() are then defined in the reference() coordinate system.

        Use position(), orientation() and magnitude() to express the frame global transformation in the world coordinate system.

        Using this method, you can create a hierarchy of frames. This hierarchy needs to be a tree, which root is the world coordinate system (i.e., null reference()). No action is performed if setting reference as the reference() would create a loop in the hierarchy.

      • settingAsReferenceWillCreateALoop

        public boolean settingAsReferenceWillCreateALoop(Frame frame)
        Returns true if setting frame as the frame's reference() would create a loop in the frame hierarchy.

      • constraint

        public Constraint constraint()
        Returns the current Constraint applied to the frame.

        A null value (default) means that no constraint is used to filter the frame translation and rotation.

        See the Constraint class documentation for details.

      • setConstraint

        public void setConstraint(Constraint constraint)
        Sets the constraint() attached to the frame.

        A null value means set no constraint (also reset it if there was one).

      • translation

        public Vector translation()
        Returns the frame translation, defined with respect to the reference().

        Use position() to get the result in world coordinates. These two values are identical when the reference() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setTranslation(Vector)

      • setTranslation

        public void setTranslation(Vector translation)
        Sets the translation() of the frame, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        Use setPosition(Vector) to define the world coordinates position().

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint)

      • translate

        public void translate(Vector vector)
        Translates the frame according to vector, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        If there's a constraint() it is satisfied. Hence the translation actually applied to the frame may differ from vector (since it can be filtered by the constraint()).

        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion), scale(float)

      • position

        public Vector position()
        Returns the frame position defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(Vector position)
        Sets the frame position(), defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use setTranslation(Vector) to define the local frame translation (with respect to the reference()).

        Note that the potential constraint() of the frame is taken into account, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:

      • setRotation

        public void setRotation(Quaternion rotation)
        Set the current rotation. See the different Quaternion constructors.

        Sets the frame rotation(), locally defined with respect to the reference(). Use setOrientation(Quaternion) to define the world coordinates orientation().

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint), rotation(), setTranslation(Vector)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(Quaternion quaternion)
        Rotates the frame by quaternion (defined in the frame coordinate system): rotation().compose(quaternion).

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint), translate(Vector)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(Quaternion quaternion,
                   Vector point)
        Rotates the frame by the quaternion whose axis (see Quaternion.axis()) passes through point. The quaternion Quaternion.axis() is defined in the frame coordinate system, while point is defined in the world coordinate system).

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint)

        Note that the potential constraint() of the frame is taken into account, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

      • alignWithFrame

      • alignWithFrame

        public void alignWithFrame(Frame frame,
                           float threshold)
        Convenience function that simply calls alignWithFrame(frame, false, threshold)

      • alignWithFrame

        public void alignWithFrame(Frame frame,
                           boolean move,
                           float threshold)
        Aligns the frame with frame, so that two of their axis are parallel.

        If one of the X, Y and Z axis of the Frame is almost parallel to any of the X, Y, or Z axis of frame, the Frame is rotated so that these two axis actually become parallel.

        If, after this first rotation, two other axis are also almost parallel, a second alignment is performed. The two frames then have identical orientations, up to 90 degrees rotations.

        threshold measures how close two axis must be to be considered parallel. It is compared with the absolute values of the dot product of the normalized axis.

        When move is set to true, the Frame position() is also affected by the alignment. The new Frame position() is such that the frame frame position (computed with coordinatesOf(Vector), in the Frame coordinates system) does not change.

        frame may be null and then represents the world coordinate system (same convention than for the reference()).

      • projectOnLine

        public void projectOnLine(Vector origin,
                          Vector direction)
        Translates the frame so that its position() lies on the line defined by origin and direction (defined in the world coordinate system).

        Simply uses an orthogonal projection. direction does not need to be normalized.

      • setXAxis

        public void setXAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its xAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        xAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

      • setYAxis

        public void setYAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its yAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        yAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

      • setZAxis

        public void setZAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its zAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        zAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

        public Matrix matrix()
        Returns the local transformation matrix represented by the frame.

        This method could be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify a graph modelView() matrix from a frame hierarchy. For example, with this frame hierarchy:

        Frame body = new Frame();
        Frame leftArm = new Frame();
        Frame rightArm = new Frame();
        leftArm.setReference(body);
        rightArm.setReference(body);

        The associated drawing code should look like:

        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(body.matrix());
        drawBody();
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(leftArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        graph.popModelView();
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(rightArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        graph.popModelView();
        graph.popModelView();

        Note the use of nested pushModelView() and popModelView() blocks to represent the frame hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

        This matrix only represents the local frame transformation (i.e., with respect to the reference()). Use worldMatrix() to get the full Frame transformation matrix (i.e., from the world to the Frame coordinate system). These two match when the reference() is null. Attention: In Processing this technique is inefficient because papplet.applyMatrix will try to calculate the inverse of the transform. Use Graph.applyTransformation(Frame) instead.

        See Also:
        setMatrix(Frame), worldMatrix(), view()

      • worldMatrix

        public Matrix worldMatrix()
        Returns the global transformation matrix represented by the frame.

        This method should be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify a graph modelView() matrix from a frame:

        // Here the modelview matrix corresponds to the world coordinate system.
        Frame frame = new Frame(translation, new Rotation(from, to));
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyModelView(frame.worldMatrix());
        // draw object in the frame coordinate system.
        graph.popModelView();

        This matrix represents the global frame transformation: the entire reference() hierarchy is taken into account to define the frame transformation from the world coordinate system. Use matrix() to get the local frame transformation matrix (i.e. defined with respect to the reference()). These two match when the reference() is null.

        See Also:
        setWorldMatrix(Frame), matrix(), view()

      • view

        public Matrix view()
        Same as worldMatrix(), but the view matrix is computing with the frame magnitude set to 1, i.e., returns the matrix associated with the frame position and orientation. To be used when the frame represents an eye.

        The view matrix converts from the world coordinates system to the eye coordinates system, so that coordinates can then be projected on screen using a projection matrix.

        See Also:
        matrix(), worldMatrix(), setMatrix(Frame), setWorldMatrix(Frame)

      • fromMatrix

        public void fromMatrix(Matrix matrix)
        Convenience function that simply calls fromMatrix(matrix, 1)).
        See Also:
        fromMatrix(Matrix, float)

      • fromMatrix

        public void fromMatrix(Matrix matrix,
                       float scaling)
        Sets the frame from a Matrix representation: rotation in the upper left 3x3 matrix and translation on the last column. Scaling is defined separately in scaling.

        Hence, if your openGL code fragment looks like:

        float [] m = new float [16]; m[0]=...;
        gl.glMultMatrixf(m);

        It is equivalent to write:

        Frame frame = new Frame();
        frame.fromMatrix(m);
        graph.applyModelView(frame.matrix());

        Using this conversion, you can benefit from the powerful frame transformation methods to translate points and vectors to and from the frame coordinate system to any other frame coordinate system (including the world coordinate system). See coordinatesOf(Vector) and transformOf(Vector).

      • setWorldMatrix

        public void setWorldMatrix(Frame other)
        Sets position(), orientation() and magnitude() values from those of the other frame.

        After calling setWorldMatrix(other) a call to this.matches(other) should return true.

        See Also:
        worldMatrix(), setMatrix(Frame)

      • setMatrix

        public void setMatrix(Frame other)
        Sets translation(), rotation() and scaling() values from those of the other frame.
        See Also:
        matrix(), setWorldMatrix(Frame)

      • inverse

        public Frame inverse()
        Returns a frame representing the inverse of this frame space transformation.

        The the new frame rotation() is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original rotation. Its translation() is the negated inverse rotated image of the original translation. Its scaling() is 1 / original scaling.

        If a frame is considered as a space rigid transformation, i.e., translation and rotation, but no scaling (scaling=1), the inverse() frame performs the inverse transformation.

        Only the local frame transformation (i.e., defined with respect to the reference()) is inverted. Use worldInverse() for a global inverse.

        The resulting frame has the same reference() as the this frame and a null constraint().

        See Also:
        worldInverse()

      • worldInverse

        public Frame worldInverse()
        Returns the inverse() of the frame world transformation.

        The orientation() of the new frame is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original orientation. Its position() is the negated and inverse rotated image of the original position. The magnitude() is the the original magnitude multiplicative inverse.

        The result frame has a null reference() and a null constraint().

        Use inverse() for a local (i.e., with respect to reference()) transformation inverse.

        See Also:
        inverse()

      • coordinatesOfFrom

        public Vector coordinatesOfFrom(Vector src,
                                Frame from)
        Returns the frame coordinates of the point whose position in the from coordinate system is src (converts from from to this frame).

        coordinatesOfIn(Vector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • coordinatesOfIn

        public Vector coordinatesOfIn(Vector vector,
                              Frame in)
        Returns the in coordinates of the point whose position in the frame coordinate system is src (converts from this frame to in).

        coordinatesOfFrom(Vector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • localCoordinatesOf

        public Vector localCoordinatesOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the frame coordinates of a point src defined in the reference() coordinate system (converts from reference() to this frame).

        localInverseCoordinatesOf(Vector) performs the inverse conversion.

        See Also:
        localTransformOf(Vector)

      • coordinatesOf

        public Vector coordinatesOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the frame coordinates of a point src defined in the world coordinate system (converts from world to this frame).

        inverseCoordinatesOf(Vector) performs the inverse conversion. transformOf(Vector) converts vectors instead of coordinates.

      • transformOfFrom

        public Vector transformOfFrom(Vector vector,
                              Frame from)
        Returns the frame transform of the vector whose coordinates in the from coordinate system is src (converts vectors from from to this frame).

        transformOfIn(Vector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • transformOfIn

        public Vector transformOfIn(Vector vector,
                            Frame in)
        Returns the in transform of the vector whose coordinates in the frame coordinate system is src (converts vectors from this frame to in).

        transformOfFrom(Vector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • localInverseCoordinatesOf

        public Vector localInverseCoordinatesOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the reference() coordinates of a point src defined in the frame coordinate system (converts from this frame to reference()).

        localCoordinatesOf(Vector) performs the inverse conversion.

        See Also:
        localInverseTransformOf(Vector)

      • inverseCoordinatesOf

        public Vector inverseCoordinatesOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the world coordinates of the point whose position in the frame coordinate system is src (converts from this frame to world).

        coordinatesOf(Vector) performs the inverse conversion. Use inverseTransformOf(Vector) to transform vectors instead of coordinates.

      • transformOf

        public Vector transformOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the frame transform of a vector src defined in the world coordinate system (converts vectors from world to this frame).

        inverseTransformOf(Vector) performs the inverse transformation. coordinatesOf(Vector) converts coordinates instead of vectors (here only the rotational part of the transformation is taken into account).

      • inverseTransformOf

        public Vector inverseTransformOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the world transform of the vector whose coordinates in the frame coordinate system is src (converts vectors from this frame to world).

        transformOf(Vector) performs the inverse transformation. Use inverseCoordinatesOf(Vector) to transform coordinates instead of vectors.

      • localTransformOf

        public Vector localTransformOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the frame transform of a vector src defined in the reference() coordinate system (converts vectors from reference() to this frame).

        localInverseTransformOf(Vector) performs the inverse transformation.

        See Also:
        localCoordinatesOf(Vector)

      • localInverseTransformOf

        public Vector localInverseTransformOf(Vector vector)
        Returns the reference() transform of a vector src defined in the Frame coordinate system (converts vectors from this frame to reference()).

        localTransformOf(Vector) performs the inverse transformation.

        See Also:
        localInverseCoordinatesOf(Vector)
